facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 101 of 1959 was filed by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 8, 1957 of the Deputy Custodian General.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 101 of 1959. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 8, 1957, of the Deputy Custodian General, Evacuee Property, Now Delhi Revision Petition No. 17-R/55 of 1955.

facts.text: Appellants are displaced persons from West Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants who are admittedly displaced persons from West Pakistan were granted quasi- permanent allotment of 24 standard acres and 15 3/4 units in the village of Raikot in Ludhiana District in 1949.

facts.text: Appellants were granted quasi-permanent allotment of 24 standard acres and 15 3/4 units in village Raikot, Ludhiana District in 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants who are admittedly displaced persons from West Pakistan were granted quasi- permanent allotment of 24 standard acres and 15 3/4 units in the village of Raikot in Ludhiana District in 1949.

facts.text: Sardar Nand Singh, father of appellants, was allotted quasi-permanent 40 standard acres and 5 1/4 units in village Humbran, Ludhiana District.

anchor.surface_text: Their father Sardar Nand Singh who was found entitled to quasi-permanent allotment of 40 standard acres and 5 1/4 units of land was given quasipermanent allotment in another village named Humbran in the same district.

facts.text: Raikot and Humbran villages are 25 miles distant from each other.

anchor.surface_text: The two villages are, however, 25 miles or so distant from each other.

facts.text: Nand Singh applied for consolidation of his lands with appellants' lands in Raikot.

anchor.surface_text: Nand Singh, therefore, made an application for companysolidation of his lands with those of the appellants in the village Raikot.

facts.text: Nand Singh died during pendency of consolidation application; appellants continued it.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of this application he died and after his death, the, application was companytinued by the appellants.

facts.text: Assistant Custodian rejected consolidation application on July 23, 1951, as no land available in Raikot.

anchor.surface_text: This application was rejected by the Assistant Custodian on July 23, 1951 on the ground that numberland was available in the village Raikot.

facts.text: Additional Custodian dismissed revision petition on August 20, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: A revision petition preferred by the appellants against the order of the Assistant Custodian was dismissed by the Additional Custodian on August 20, 1952.

facts.text: Appellants filed revision before Custodian General on October 7, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: On October 7, 1952 the appellants preferred a revision application before the Custodian General.

facts.text: Additional Custodian cancelled allotment of 14 quasi-permanent allottees in Karodian village.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the revision application the Additional Custodian for the State of Punjab cancelled the allotment of fourteen quasi-permanent allottees of the village Karodian in the same district on the ground that these persons were entitled to allotment of suburban land a had been wrongly fitted in the village Karodian.

facts.text: On October 31, 1952, Additional Custodian cancelled appellants' Raikot allotment and allotted Karodian land in substitution.

anchor.surface_text: Acting suo motu the Additional Custodian made an order on October 31, 1952 cancelling the order of allotment of land in the village Raikot made in favour of the appellants in the year 1949 and instead allotted to them land in Karodian in substitution of ,the lands at Raikot and of the lands allotted to their father.

facts.text: Karodian land allotted to appellants was from land released after cancellation of 14 allottees.

anchor.surface_text: The land allotted was out of the land released upon the cancellation of allotment of lands in favour of the aforementioned 14 allottees.

facts.text: 14 Karodian allottees applied for review of their cancellation order.

anchor.surface_text: These fourteen allottees preferred an application for review of the order cancelling their allotment on the ground that this cancellation was a result of misapprehension of the actual facts and that they were number entitled to allotment of suburban lands at all.

facts.text: Appellants applied for review of Raikot cancellation order.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants also preferred an application for review of the order cancelling their quasi- permanent allotment in the village Raikot.

facts.text: Additional Custodian recommended restoration of land to 14 Karodian allottees.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Custodian for the State of Punjab recommended to the Custodian General the restoration of the land to the 14 allottees which had been taken away from them by reason of cancellation of the allotment in their favour by the order dated October 31, 1952.

facts.text: Additional Custodian dismissed appellants' review application citing r.14(6) effective July 22, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Custodian, however, dismissed the application on the ground that r. 14 6  of the Evacuee Property Rules which came into force on July 22, 1952, stood in the way of cancellation of the allotment in favour of the appellant.

facts.text: Deputy Custodian General on December 17, 1954 revised and restored land to 14 Karodian allottees, cancelling appellants' Karodian allotment.

anchor.surface_text: On December 17, 1954, the Deputy Custodian General, before whom these allottees had preferred an application for revision, revised the order of the Additional Custodian and restored to the 14 allottees of Karodian the land which had been originally allotted to them. and allotment of which had been cancelled earlier.

facts.text: Appellants on January 6, 1955 moved Deputy Custodian General to revise October 31, 1952 order cancelling Raikot allotment.

anchor.surface_text: On January 6, 1955, the appellants moved the Deputy Custodian General for calling up their review application and for revising the order of October 31, 1952 passed by the Additional Custodian cancelling the allotment of Raikot lands which had originally been made in their favour in the year 1949.

facts.text: After cancellation of appellants' Raikot allotment, land allotted to respondents 2 to 4.

anchor.surface_text: Consequent upon the cancellation of the appellants allotment of the Raikot land they were allotted to respondents 2 to 4.

facts.text: Deputy Custodian General dismissed appellants' application on November 8, 1957 citing Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Act, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: By the order dated November 8, 1957 the Deputy Custodian General dismissed the appellants application.

facts.text: Central Government notification S.R.O. 697 dated March 24, 1955 acquired evacuee property allotted under Punjab notification July 8, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that by numberification S. R. 0. 697 dated March 24, 1955 the Central Government decided to acquire all evacuee property allotted to displaced persons by the Custodian under the Conditions companytained in the numberification of the Government of Punjab in the Department of Rehabilitation, No. 4892-6 dated July 8, 1949, except certain categories of property specified in the schedule.

facts.text: Raikot lands allotted to appellants under Punjab notification dated July 8, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The Raikot lands were allotted to the appellants under the aforesaid numberification of the Government of Punjab.

facts.text: Raikot lands do not fall within excepted categories in acquisition notification schedule.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed on their behalf that they do number fall within any of the excepted categories of property, set out in the schedule.

facts.text: Appellants ceased to hold and lost possession of Raikot lands before March 24, 1955 notification.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that the appellants ceased to hold and had lost possession of the Raikot lands before the publication of this numberification.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 8, 1957, of the Deputy Custodian General, Evacuee Property, Now Delhi

issues.text: Whether the jurisdiction of the Deputy Custodian General to revise the order cancelling the quasi-permanent allotment of Raikot lands has been taken away by the Displaced Persons (Compensation and Rehabilitation) Act, 1954 and the notification under s.12 issued on March 24, 1955

anchor.surface_text: The ground on which the appellants application was rejected by the Deputy Custodian General was that his jurisdiction to revise the order has been taken away by virtue of the provisions of Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Act, 1954, 44 of 1954 and the notification issued thereunder on March 24, 1955.

issues.text: Whether the publication of notification under s.12(1) of the 1954 Act divests the Custodian of powers under the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950 to deal with allotments of acquired evacuee property

anchor.surface_text: Section 12 of the 1954 Act empowers the Central Government to acquire evacuee property for rehabilitation of displaced persons by publishing in the official gazette a notification to the effect that it has decided to acquire such evacuee property in pursuance of this provision.

issues.text: Whether s.19 of the 1954 Act prevails over s.10 of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950 and confers exclusive power on managing officer to cancel allotments of acquired evacuee property

anchor.surface_text: Section 19 of the Act provides that notwithstanding anything contained in any contract or any other law for the time being in force but subject to the rules that may be made under the Act the managing officer or managing corporation may cancel any allotment etc.

issues.text: Whether the appellants are entitled to protection and continuation in possession under s.10 of the 1954 Act despite cancellation of allotment

anchor.surface_text: Section 10 runs as follows Special procedure for payment of compensation in certain cases.-Where any immovable property has been leased or allotted to a displaced person by the Custodian

issues.text: Whether the Custodian could rectify the error in cancelling the allotment after the property was divested by s.12 notification as he had become functus officio

anchor.surface_text: had become functus officio with respect to it and could not rectify any error made by him in the past in the matter of cancellation of allotment.

issues.text: Whether the cancellation of appellants' allotment complied with condition No.6 of the 1949 Punjab notification limiting grounds for resumption or cancellation

anchor.surface_text: under condition No. 6 the Custodian or rehabilitation authority would be competent to resume or cancel an allotment only on one of the grounds set out in that condition.

arguments.claim: Publication of s.12(1) notification divests Custodian of title and powers under s.8 and s.10 of Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950

anchor.surface_text: But the consequence of the publication of the notification by the Central Government under s. 12 1 of the Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Act with respect to any property or a class of property would be to divest the Custodian completely of his right in the property flowing from s. 8 of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950,

arguments.claim: s.19 of 1954 Act non-obstante clause prevails over s.10 of 1950 Act; only managing officer can cancel allotments of acquired property

anchor.surface_text: Section 19 of the Act provides that notwithstanding anything contained in any contract or any other law for the time being in force but subject to the rules that may be made under the Act the managing officer or managing corporation may cancel any allotment etc.

arguments.claim: Custodian became functus officio after s.12 notification and cannot rectify past erroneous cancellation

anchor.surface_text: had become functus officio with respect to it and could not rectify any error made by him in the past in the matter of cancellation of allotment.

arguments.claim: Additional Custodian correctly applied r.14(6) Evacuee Property Rules barring cancellation of appellants' Karodian allotment

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Custodian, however, dismissed the application on the ground that r. 14 6 of the Evacuee Property Rules which came into force on July 22, 1952, stood in the way of cancellation of the allotment in favour of the appellant.

holdings.text: Publication of the notification under s.12(1) of the Displaced Persons (Compensation and Rehabilitation) Act, 1954 divests the Custodian completely of his right in the property under s.8 of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950 and vests it in the Central Government.

anchor.surface_text: But the consequence of the publication of the notification by the Central Government under s. 12 1  of the Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Act with respect to any property or a class of property would be to divest the Custodian completely of his right in the property flowing from s. 8 of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950,

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.12(2) extinguishes evacuee rights and vests property in Central Govt; Custodian's powers depend on vesting under s.8 AEP 1950 which is divested; no provision allows Custodian to deal post-vesting.

holdings.text: s.19 of the 1954 Act confers power to cancel allotments of acquired evacuee property only on managing officer or corporation, notwithstanding any other law including s.10 of AEP Act 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Section 19 of the Act provides that notwithstanding anything contained in any contract or any other law for the time being in force but subject to the rules that may be made under the Act the managing officer or managing corporation may cancel any allotment etc.,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Non-obstante clause in s.19 prevails over conflicting s.10 AEP; no mention of Custodian; post-acquisition, only managing officer empowered.

holdings.text: Jurisdiction of Deputy Custodian General to revise order cancelling Raikot allotment taken away by 1954 Act and s.12 notification dated March 24, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The ground on which the appellants application was rejected by the Deputy Custodian General was that his jurisdiction to revise the order has been taken away by virtue of the provisions of Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Act, 1954, 44 of 1954 and the notification issued thereunder on March 24, 1955.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Combines effect of s.12 divestment and s.19 exclusive power to managing officer; follows Bal Mukund v. State of Punjab; no continuation of pre-1954 Act proceedings.

holdings.text: Appellants not entitled to continue in possession or protection under s.10 of 1954 Act as they were not in possession of Raikot lands on date of acquisition notification.

anchor.surface_text: Section 10 runs as follows Special procedure for payment of compensation in certain cases.-Where any immovable property has been leased or allotted to a displaced person by the Custodian

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.10 implicitly requires possession on notification date; appellants undisputedly lost possession before March 24, 1955; even if cancellation erroneous, possession fact decisive.

holdings.text: Custodian became functus officio after s.12 notification and could not rectify past error in cancelling allotment.

anchor.surface_text: had become functus officio with respect to it and could not rectify any error made by him in the past in the matter of cancellation of allotment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Divestment under s.12 terminates Custodian's authority over property; no power to revisit past decisions post-divestment.

holdings.text: Cancellation of allotment may or may not have violated condition No.6 of 1949 Punjab notification, but irrelevant as appellants lost possession before notification and Custodian functus officio.

anchor.surface_text: under condition No. 6 the Custodian or rehabilitation authority would be competent to resume or cancel an allotment only on one of the grounds set out in that condition. He said that the cancellation of the allotment in favour of the appellants was impermissible

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assumes arguendo but holds immaterial due to possession loss and functus officio; not necessary to decision.

holdings.text: r.74 of 1955 Rules does not prohibit Custodian from allotting Raikot property to respondents pending proceedings before Custodian General.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Achhruram contended that r. 74 of the Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Rules, 1955 stood in the way of the Custodian allotting the Raikot property

holdings.reasoning_summary: r.74 in Chapter X concerns final transfers under s.10 for compensation, not quasi-permanent allotments under AEP 1950; applies to 1954 Act authorities only.

holdings.text: s.19(1) not restricted by s.17 or r.102 to entrusted properties or specified grounds; r.102(d) allows cancellation for any sufficient reason.

anchor.surface_text: He then contends that the provisions of s. 19 1  of the Act being subject to rules made under the Act must be read along with r. 102 which deals with cancellation of allotments

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of non-entrustment; s.19 particular provision prevails over general s.17; r.102(d) broadens to 'any other sufficient reason'; acquired property no longer evacuee property.

precedents.citation: Bal Mukund v. The State of Punjab 1

anchor.surface_text: In taking this view he has relied upon the decision in Bal Mukund v. The State of Punjab 1 . In that case the Court has held that the powers of the Custodian General to deal with matters of this kind have been taken away by the Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Act, 1954, and that these powers now vest in another authority and that there is no provision for continuing the pro- ceedings which had been commenced under the Administration of Evacuee Property Act., 1950, but had

precedents.case_name: Bal Mukund v. The State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: powers of the Custodian General to deal with matters of this kind have been taken away by the Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Act, 1954, and that these powers now vest in another authority and that there is no provision for continuing the proceedings which had been commenced under the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950, but had not been concluded

Rule 74, Displaced Persons (Compensation and Rehabilitation) Rules, 1955 support
Section 17, Displaced Persons (Compensation and Rehabilitation) Act, 1954 support

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is accordingly dismissed.

outcome.relief_summary: The appeal is dismissed; application of the appellants rejected, upholding the order of the Deputy Custodian General.

anchor.surface_text: But the consequence of the publication of the notification by the Central Government under s. 12 1  of the Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Act with respect to any property or a class of property would be to divest the Custodian completely of his right in the property flowing from s. 8 of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950,
The appeal is accordingly dismissed.

Section 19 of the Act provides that notwithstanding anything contained in any contract or any other law for the time being in force but subject to the rules that may be made under the Act the managing officer or managing corporation may cancel any allotment etc.,
The appeal is accordingly dismissed.
